@jacquipark @DailiesMidas @nordschleswiger @JM_Flensborg @Flensborg_Avis @hblwebb @CatalunyaDiari @TagblattD @adzrumaenien @primorskiD 8/8 @moussajamaat from @baynanaes says: “Our magazine aims to offer useful information to the Arabic-speaking community in Spain and, at the same time, build bridges between migrants, refugees and Spanish people of foreign origin, and the rest of the population.”

@jacquipark @DailiesMidas @nordschleswiger @JM_Flensborg @Flensborg_Avis @hblwebb @CatalunyaDiari @TagblattD @adzrumaenien 7/8 @primorskiD says its most valued service is the early-morning home delivery service. “The service is expensive, but brings strong loyalty.” However, costs restrict delivery to potential readers outside the paper’s core area. He calls for a new digital marketing strategy.

@jacquipark @DailiesMidas @nordschleswiger @JM_Flensborg @Flensborg_Avis @hblwebb @CatalunyaDiari @TagblattD 6/8 In #Romania, the @adzrumaenien aims to match its reporting to the German-speaking community in the country with reporting on Romania to German speakers across #Europe (including German-speaking Romanians now living in Germany).

@jacquipark @DailiesMidas @nordschleswiger @JM_Flensborg @Flensborg_Avis @hblwebb @CatalunyaDiari 5/8 In South Tyrol, @TagblattD has long acted as the local news voice in the regional (German) language. Like all daily papers, its audience is ageing, and it is relying on experiments with its on-line arm to draw younger readers.

@jacquipark @DailiesMidas @nordschleswiger @JM_Flensborg @Flensborg_Avis @hblwebb 4/8 In #Spain, @CatalunyaDiari say that their current audience is older Catalan speakers, both nationally and rooted in the region. “Our goal,” they say, “would be to reach young people and the new population.”

@jacquipark @DailiesMidas @nordschleswiger @JM_Flensborg @Flensborg_Avis 3/8 One of #Finland’s leading Swedish language papers, @hblwebb, says its average audience age is close to 60. To expand, they launched a parallel youth-focused newspaper and introduced special subscription deals for schools and university students.

@jacquipark @DailiesMidas @nordschleswiger 2/8 Danish-language news outlet in #Flensburg on the German-side of the border has transformed into a Danish-language voice on the border. As @JM_Flensborg of @Flensborg_Avis says of their biggest challenge: “To keep together the coherence within the Danish minority in Germany.”

@jacquipark @DailiesMidas 1/8 The German-language newspaper @nordschleswiger in southern Denmark has transformed from an information source for the small German-speaking community in Denmark into a German-language voice for the border communities.

@jacquipark @DailiesMidas The report is based on thirteen deep interviews with minority-media news leaders and media thinkers.

Here are some insights 👇

@jacquipark @DailiesMidas Minority- and regional-language media are central to the media ecosystem, particularly across the diverse linguistic landscape of #Europe and the #EU. They bring a unique offering to their community while adapting to the opportunities of the digital transition.

📣With authoritarianism & illiberalism on the rise, democratic governments must lead by example. 

On #WPFD2022, @globalfreemedia offers 10 recommendations for what democratic governments must do to better protect #pressfreedom at home & around the world.

https://t.co/ZbYAi6TMBl

10/10: Create an enabling environment for press freedom by:
⚡️building trust in the media 
⚡️ensuring fair market conditions to prevent media capture 
⚡️funding independent and local journalism
9/10: Make the promotion and protection of press freedom core elements of foreign policy – and hold other governments accountable for crimes against journalists or attacks on the media.
8/10: Support the work of civil society organizations that promote and defend press freedom.
7/10: Bolster support for multilateral and regional human rights bodies and mechanisms that protect fundamental freedom of expression rights and hold gov'ts accountable to human rights obligations.
6/10: Show zero tolerance for attacks on the press – and vigorously defend journalists from verbal harassment, online and offline, and from physical threats, assaults, and harm.

5/10: Refrain from unlawful surveillance of journalists and civil society. Gov’s must adopt rigorous human rights safeguards protecting journalists and civil society from illegal or arbitrary surveillance.
4/10: Ensure that the fight against disinformation cannot be used to restrict freedom of expression, which gives cover to repressive regimes to do much worse.

3/10: Refrain from regulating social media in ways that are inconsistent with int’l human rights and that undercut freedom of expression and access to information rights: Online spaces must remain free and open channels for independent news and independent voices.
2/10: Avoid enacting or applying laws that can be used as precedents by authoritarian regimes to restrict the work of the press or to punish critical journalism.

1/10: Protect press freedom at home. Democracies must first put their own house in order by shoring up protections for press freedom at home which will enable them to credibly defend media freedom around the world.

#Pressfreedom is under siege in every part of the world. Democratic gov’ts must do more to protect independent media and freedom of the press at home and abroad. 
#WPFD2022 
Check out our recommendations: 👇🧵

Unser Monitoring erfasst auch die schweren Repressionen in Russland:

- 114 Nachrichten-Websites von der Regulierungsbehörde blockiert.

- Mindestens 10 große Sender/Zeitungen geschlossen.

- 49 Journalist*innen festgenommen, als sie über Antikriegsproteste berichteten.

Mindestens 7 Journalist*innen wurden in der Ukraine in Ausübung ihrer Tätigkeit getötet. 

In 33 anderen Fällen wurden Journalist*innen, die von der Front in der Ukraine berichteten, angegriffen, beschossen oder von Granaten getroffen.

Our report is also published days after a Turkish court sentenced prominent philanthropist Osman Kavala to life in prison – one of the most shocking examples yet of the radical instrumentalization of the Turkish justice system to punish government critics, including journalists.

The report comes as government announces that new draft law on disinfo will be sent to parliament soon.

While AKP claims law is based on EU’s Digital Services Act and would protect human rights, it is likely to result in further clampdown on free expression.

⚡️Launching our latest Turkey mission report: Digital censorship is growing, while the space for independent journalism shrinks further.

Read the full conclusions of our report on media freedom and pluralism in Hungary, published last month.

https://t.co/qFdhIWVWn5

The majority of news sources are under direct or indirect gov control. The remaining independent media face systematic discrimination, while the public broadcaster functions as a state propaganda outlet. This massive erosion of media freedom took place on the EU's watch.
The engines of this model of media capture include the massive abuse of state ad funding, politically controlled media regulation, and a network of govt-allied oligarchs acting as proxies.

Fidesz has applied an aggressive model of media capture, exploiting the power of the state to gain control over public media, concentrate private media in the hands of allies, and distort the market to the detriment of independent journalism.

Viktor Orbán secures another supermajority in Hungary after a decade-long effort to gain political control over the media.

Orbán's Fidesz party systematically eroded media pluralism to build a vast pro-govt media empire. 

Our report shows how 🔽

https://t.co/qFdhIWVWn5

@KhabarLahariya Renowned for its credibility, @KhabarLahariya relies on journalists embedded in and from the target communities to counter disinformation and inform its monthly audience of up to 10 million people.

@KhabarLahariya “All of our stories have that core idea of our rural and urban women coming together, an all-women crew shooting, telling stories with a bottom-up approach,” says the @KhabarLahariya team.

@KhabarLahariya Eighteen years later, the “country’s only digital rural network” is thriving, employing about 40 women journalists from socially and economically marginalized groups to report on issues that directly impact their communities.

@KhabarLahariya Khabar Lahariya offers hyper-local watchdog journalism with a feminist lens. Founded by a Delhi-based NGO as a weekly print edition in 2002, @KhabarLahariya began as a women’s collective led by a group of urban and rural feminists.

We’re highlighting the fabulous media outlets from IPI's #MediaSurvivalGuide report--follow along to read about the all-women team of reporters from the Indian hinterland @KhabarLahariya in #Bundelkhand #India

@kloopnews @bektour In addition to producing top-notch journalism, @kloopnews also runs a media literacy school for Kyrgyz youth and has an election monitoring department, which builds demand for trustworthy local news across both urban and rural spaces in #Kyrgyzstan.

@kloopnews @bektour “We are, I think, balancing on the edge of activism and journalism - I don’t know if it’s right or wrong, but we just feel like in #Kyrgyzstan, it’s something we have to do these days,” says @bektour.
@kloopnews @bektour Seeking to hold those in power accountable and improve the quality of the media for local communities in Kyrgyzstan, Kloop refuses to give into pressure from external influence.

@kloopnews Founded in 2007 by @bektour and Rinat Tuhvatshin, @kloopnews became especially prominent in 2010 for its coverage of the Kyrgyz revolution and its investigations into alleged criminal activities of the son of the president of #Kyrgyzstan.

IPI’s #MediaSurvivalGuide launched earlier this month. We’re highlighting the fabulous media outlets from the report--follow along to read about how @kloopnews in #Kyrgyzstan is fearlessly holding the Kyrgyz government accountable ⤵️

@citizenmatters Ultimately, @citizenmatters’s strength is the audience: people who are engaged in civic issues in
their community. Having them as both readers and contributors creates a feedback loop and ensures impact on the ground.
@citizenmatters The paper has three chapters, in Bengaluru, Mumbai, and Chennai. Coverage has expanded to other areas such as Delhi, Hyderabad, and cities such as Pune and Ahmedabad.

@citizenmatters “We created a platform for civic participation in journalism to be a more reflective and inclusive publication, that drew from the truth of people’s experiences and could push for change, as a guide to newsworthiness determination”, co-founder@meerak says.
@citizenmatters In #India, the Bangalore-based Citizen Matters integrates citizens and editors to tell stories about the challenges facing the urban centres of Bangalore, Chennai, and Mumbai.

📌 IPI’s #MediaSurvivalGuide launched last week. We’re highlighting the fabulous media outlets from the report. Follow along to read about how @citizenmatters in #India delves into hyperlocal issues, deviating from media’s focus on national news ⤵️

18 months of media persecution.

The IPI global network stands with all our Belarusian colleagues, both those who have been forced to flee and those still working within the country.

- 68 suffered violence
- Over 140 raids on media
- 33 journalists still behind bars. 

World must not lose focus on this brutal repression.

With a focus on local citizen participation and a range of revenue sources including membership models, paid advertising and partnerships, Latin American news orgs are making new media sustainable for the challenges ahead. 

Read more 🔽

https://t.co/1lYTX6uFte

When asked about the secret to their success, @eldebate editor @andreaDBT says it’s about being open to experimentation and trust.

"The first thing is letting the people on the team have ownership over things...and then, get out of their way."

"At first we were just catching up," says @andreaDBT, editor of Mexico's @eldebate says, "but then we realized there was a lot to gain." Today, El Debate runs 16 different online iterations of its print edition while remaining loyal to its local audience.

Like Red/Acción, Paraguay's @elsurti is not chasing breaking news. 

“We set out to make our journalism more phenomenal than factual”, co-founder @alejandrovaldez says. It's not about the plain facts, but about the reasons and relationships behind them.

https://t.co/1lYTX6uFte

It’s about hacking the old model, Red/Acción founder @chaniguyot says, and providing an "antidote against news intoxication".

Instead of negativity and polarization, it's engaging audiences around issues that matter.

https://t.co/1lYTX6uFte

Across Latin America, digital and local media are breaking the mold, testing innovations and new revenue streams as part of a reimagination of public-interest journalism.

We profile three of them: @elsurti 🇵🇾 @ELDEBATE 🇲🇽 @redaccioncomar 🇦🇷 

https://t.co/1lYTX6uFte

Local reporting is central to democratic accountability, but is under growing pressure. That's why IPI has a full programme to understand best practices and challenges #localnews face today. The project kickstarted w/ @craignewmark support.

Main lessons👇
https://t.co/Wa7mmyZtVd

@jacquipark @SteveCollNY @Report4America With @FNFreiheit, we’re now focusing on about 16 local media voices in the APac, Sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America, Eastern Europe and MENA regions. If you’re building or transitioning local media in these regions, @jacquipark @globalfreemedia want to hear from you. 8/8

@jacquipark @SteveCollNY @Report4America The IPI #LocalJournalismProject researches how #localnews orgs innovate and adapt to build #sustainable models. We want to gather this knowledge and share it to help strengthen quality news outlets serving local communities around the world. 7/8

@jacquipark @SteveCollNY @Report4America The #digitaltransition is an opportunity to build sustainable media that better serve communities through innovation and experimentation. It’s already happening, but it’s unevenly distributed, particularly outside North America and Europe. 6/8

@jacquipark @SteveCollNY @Report4America Around the world, traditional #localnews media are in crisis, grappling with challenges of scale and funding, and the battle for attention. For many new media ventures, too, this is a critical moment of transition that the pandemic has made tougher. 5/8

@jacquipark @SteveCollNY It’s well known the loss of #localnews media leads to a decline in informed civic participation, resulting in a negative loop and the rise of deliberate, organized disinformation. 4/8 @Report4America

@jacquipark At #IPIWoCo2021 w/ @SteveCollNY said, “Local reporting is the bedrock of democratic participation ... It’s the court of last resort for people who need to hold powerful people accountable.” 3/8 https://t.co/53jZe1bCWs

@jacquipark There’s plenty of talk about the rebirth of #localnews. But here’s a question that needs more attention: what’s happening with local media in developing societies, outside Western Europe and North America? 2/8 https://t.co/k8HhxpowRp

In our worldwide look at  #localnews, IPI’s @jacquipark found it’s the most disrupted sector of the media, the most urgently in need of assistance, and has the greatest potential to form the bedrock for a new, stronger media ecosystem. 1/8

@craignewmark @jacquipark @khadijapatel @Appalachia100 @poetabook 4. To succeed, engage local communities from design to editorial decision-making, and demonstrate continued value to the community, particularly sectors historically excluded from coverage. 

Big lesson from @KhabarLahariya and @mekomit: Write for, not about, communities. 6/14

@craignewmark @jacquipark @khadijapatel 3. Successful #localnews media have a clear sense of their mission, editorial vision and audience when they reflect their communities. This confidence is guiding a reimagining of journalism to meet their needs, like @Appalachia100 @poetabook. 5/14

@craignewmark @jacquipark 2. Where there’s a digital transition infrastructure, it’s supporting innovation & experimentation, having a strong positive impact on local media, but it’s unevenly distributed and often missing outside North America and Europe. That’s a gap for #philanthropy @khadijapatel 4/14

@craignewmark @jacquipark 1. Local news media is the most disrupted sector of the media, the most urgently in need of assistance – and the sector with the greatest potential to form the bedrock for a new, stronger media ecosystem. 3/14

@craignewmark IPI’s @jacquipark talked to 30+ media leaders and entrepreneurs who are transitioning legacy media or creating new local voices, half in the #USA and half in #Asia, the Pacific, #Africa and #Europe. 

Here are some key insights 👇 2/14

What’s changing in #localnews? Just about everything - that’s what IPI found when, supported by @craignewmark, it dived into local #newsmedia around the world. They’re rethinking everything to work out what they need now to sustain vital journalism. 1/14

All those responsible for these and all other journalist killings must be brought to justice. This includes the ultimate masterminds - who are most often the ones left off the hook.

https://t.co/GyPRbgcwgc

Sadly, these cases are just the tip of the iceberg. Impunity is the reality in scores of journalist murders around the world.

The failure of states to solve these crimes fuels self-censorship, encourages more attacks, and violates the public's right to information. #EndImpunity

8. Ján Kuciak - Slovak investigative reporter for @Aktualitysk murdered with his fiancée on Feb 21, 2018. 

A well-known businessman was acquitted of orchestrating the murder - but the Slovak Supreme Court has ordered a new trial.

https://t.co/dr1eaKaAR7

7. Christopher Allen - freelancer killed in 2017 during heavy fighting in South Sudan while embedded with rebel troops. 

Despite claims that Allen was targeted by govt soldiers, South Sudan has failed to open a formal investigation.

https://t.co/GOyOS3kkjl

6. Lasantha Wickrematunge - The prominent Sri Lankan editor and IPI World Press Freedom Hero was assassinated on January 8, 2009. 

The killing remains unsolved. His daughter has filed a U.N. complaint over alleged govt involvement in the murder.

https://t.co/fENKs4GkhP

5. Regina Martínez - respected correspondent for Mexico's @proceso magazine was strangled to death at her home in Veracruz on April 28, 2012.

Regina was known for her fearless reports on human rights violations, govt corruption, and drug trafficking.

https://t.co/U7KWZWlj5t

4. Daphne Caruana Galizia - Malta's best-known investigative reporter was assassinated in a car bombing on Oct 16, 2017. 

The indictment this August of the suspected mastermind was a milestone - but the uphill battle for justice remains.

https://t.co/kezEJokeLC

3. Ahmed Hussein-Suale - shot dead in Accra, Ghana on January 16, 2019. 

Ahmed was an investigative journalist for Tiger Eye, known for its undercover exposure (led by @anasglobal) of corruption in Africa, including mass corruption in African football.

https://t.co/LRTgkMYL8c

2. IPI World Press Freedom Hero Anna Politkovskaya - murdered on Oct. 7, 2006 in her Moscow apartment building.

15 years later, the identity of the mastermind(s) behind her assassination remains unknown.

https://t.co/SsGNXm1t3z

1. Jamal Khashoggi - murdered in the Saudi Arabian consulate in Istanbul, Turkey on Oct 2, 2018. 

More than three years later, Saudi Arabia and Crown Prince MBS have suffered no consequences for this heinous act.

https://t.co/noVB7x5vdK
